The project is co-financed by four donor agencies. Project Objectives and Description: In line with the Country Assistance Strategy, the project supports the disengagement of Government from a major economic activity -rail transport services-, for the future provision of which a Concession Agreement-has been signed with a private operator. The project is part of a larger program, covering both the Ivorian and the Burkina part of the Abidjan-Ouagadougou-Kaya railways. The main program and project objective is the revitalization of a major transport service promoting competitiveness and regional integration. It provides the financing necessary to carry out the long overdue rehabilitation of the publicly-owned railway assets, that will henceforth be managed and operated by the private concessionaire; the concession fee covers, inter alia, the full debt service on the proposed investments. The main project components cover: (i) infrastructure rehabilitation and maintenance (selective replacement of rails and sleepers, reballasting, bridge and culvert repairs); (ii) repair and maintenance of motive power and rolling stock; (iii) rehabilitation and acquisition of maintenance equipment; (iv) acquisition of computers; and (v) works supervision and training. Project Benefits and Risks: The benefits quantified for the economic analysis are reduced transport costs on long distance bulk and container traffic, for which rail has an economic advantage over road transport. Re-establishment of efficient rail service will provide cost-effective transport for new mining exports expected with the development of the mining sector in Burkina. Additional but unquantified benefits are the preservation of an
 -11- important infrastructural asset that will promote regional integration, and turn rail transport from a loss-making activity requiring Government subsidization into a commercially profitable one. Risks are manageable, and would mainly result from a slower than projected increase in the traffic attracted back from road transport. However, the concessionaire who has the managerial independence to operate services on a commercial basis, has competent personnel to carry out the rehabilitation program on behalf of the patrimony corporations, and has a financial interest in doing so rapidly and thoroughly. Traffic forecasts underlying the proposed investment program are conservative, and an efficiently run railway should have no difficulty to attract back from road transport the heavy, long distance traffic its predecessors have lost due to poor operational and commercial performance. Environmental Impact: Activities financed under the project concern only rehabilitation of existing equipment and infrastructure (selective replacement of rail and sleepers on some sections of the track, re-ballasting, and repairs of bridges and culverts, all on an embankment constructed some forty years ago). Rehabilitation works will be monitored by the Ministry in charge of the environment. In addition, the concessionaire has undertaken to provide training for some of its personnel in environmental assessment and monitoring, so as to avoid negative environmental impacts during project execution and in operations.  REPUBLIC OF COTE D'IVOIRE RAILWAY REHABILITATION PROJECT CHAPTER I. COUNTRY AND SECTOR BACKGROUND A. Country Setting 1.1 Cote d'Ivoire is one of the principal countries in the CFA zone. It is endowed with a good natural resource base and has a population of some 13 million people. GDP in 1993 was estimated at US$9.3 billion. A rapid build-up of external debt in the second half of the 1970s when prices for the country's main exports, coffee and cocoa, peaked has saddled Cote d'Ivoire with the highest per capita debt in West Africa: in 1993, when prices for these two commodities had fallen to half their earlier level, the country's public external debt stood at about US$15 billion. High population growth, coupled with economic decline, has reduced per capita GNP from more than US$1,000 equivalent in the early 1980s to about US$515 equivalent in 1994. Due to mounting neglect of basic social services, social indicators have been deteriorating significantly along with the decline in standards of living over the past decade: recent estimates indicate that more than 60 percent of the population live below the poverty line, compared to about 30 percent in the mid-1980s. 1.2 A series of sector and structural adjustment programs supported by the IMF, the Bank and IDA from 1989 onward did not produce expected results, and GDP per capita contracted by a cumulative 18 percent over the 1990-1993 period. In January 1994, Cote d'lvoire, along with its partner countries in the CFA zone, decided to complement its internal adjustment efforts with external measures of adjustment by realigning the parity of the CFA franc from 50 to 100 CFA to I FF. 1.3 Preliminary results for 1994 have been encouraging: compared to other CFA countries, Cote d'lvoire has managed the devaluation relatively well and has registered its first positive growth (1.3 percent) in years. Government has succeeded in bringing inflation (0.3 percent/month in the last quarter of 1994) back to pre-devaluation levels within eight months following devaluation. This has been largely due to a restrictive wage policy adopted by Government and followed by the private sector (+ 10 percent of base wages on average). Production data for the first three quarters of 1994 suggest a positive supply response following devaluation: industrial production increased by about 30 percent overall, with significantly larger increases for textiles and wood. 1.4 As regards fiscal policy, Government has been able to meet revenue and expenditure targets set out in its 1994 Policy Framework Paper (PFP), producing a primary surplus of about 1.5 percent of GDP. Preliminary data also indicate that export volumes increased by about I percent, while import volumes fell by some 11 percent. As a result, the trade balance surplus improved by some US$365 million. 1.5 But while Government succeeded in rapidly stabilizing the economy in 1994, it still needs to deepen structural reforms, in order to realize PFP objectives which are to: (i) increase real GDP growth to 6% annually; (ii) generate increasing primary budget surpluses; (iii) strengthen external competitiveness through trade, price and regulatory reforms; (iv) intensify
 -2- human resource development and poverty alleviation efforts; and (v) protect the country's natural resource base. This will require decisive additional actions in the areas of agriculture, transport, the social sectors, and in private sector development. 1.6 Consequently, IDA's assistance strategy over the short and medium term will be to help Government: (i) strengthen public sector finances through reforms in both revenue and expenditure execution; (ii) promote private sector development through continued liberalization of trade, financial and labor markets, and through investment in agriculture, industry and transport; (iii) make the human resource development program more effective through increased focus on primary health care, AIDS, population policy and basic education; (iv) strengthen institutional capacity through existing technical assistance programs; and (v) intensify environmental work through projects and through the NEAP process. B. The Transport Sector 1.7 Transport Infrastructure. C6te d'lvoire's transport sector absorbed massive investments during the 1970s and 1980s, not all of them economically justified. The country's transport infrastructure is therefore very well developed: it has a road network of some 68,000 km, of which 5,300 km are paved; two deep water ports in Abidjan and San Pedro; three international airports (Abidjan, Bouake and Yamoussoukro) and 22 smaller airfields serving regional centers; and a single-track international railway line connecting Abidjan to Ouagadougou and Kaya (630/1,260 km in Cote d'ivoire). 1 .8 Transport sector management has been less satisfactory. The Ministry of Equipment, Transport and Telecommunications (METT) is charged with the administration of all sector activities, from planning and programming, through road maintenance works execution by force account, to supervision, coordination and regulation. A Directorate for Large-Scale Works (Direction et Contr6le des Grands Travaux, DCGTx), was first set up within the METT, but worked directly under the Presidency until 1990, when it was transferred to the Prime Minister's office. It has had a powerful role in the technical and financial auditing of activities of all major projects (costing US$1.5 million equivalent or more) in the public and parastatal sectors. While it supplanted the role of the sector ministries in works programming, procurement and supervision for well over a decade, it now works as a public sector company (Societe Nationale) under the authority of the Prime Minister, and functions as a high-powered Consulting Agency that carries out assignments on demand. Intermodal coordination, theoretically provided by the Directorate of Planning, Programming and Project Management (DPPGP) of METT, has traditionally been, and remains, weak. 1.9 Problems and Policy Issues. A large-scale National Transport Plan study was carried out in 1989, followed by a Bank sector review in 1991 which covered the road, rail, maritime and air transport subsectors. The study identified major problems and policy issues in the areas of investment planning, of infrastructure maintenance financing, of operation and management of the main public enterprises active in the sector, and in the existing regulatory framework for transport activities. A proposed IDA Transport Sector Loan, designed to address some of these problems, became stalled over disagreements on the scope of proposed reforms. Preparation of a subsequently proposed Road Maintenance and Rehabilitation Project has also been slow. While the dialogue continues, it is becoming increasingly evident, that the absence of decisive transport sector reform not only adds needless costs to local transactions, thus hampering efficient functioning of internal markets and delivery of social services, but is also very damaging to COte d'lvoire's competitiveness in external markets. Redress of some of the most costly monopoly practices in the maritime transport sector has been achieved under

The one subsector where significant reforms, promoted under the ongoing Privatization Support Project (Cr. 2363-IVC) have actually been introduced over the past two years, is railways. C. Developments in the Railway Subsector 1.10 The railway, a 1,260 km single track metric line constructed between 1904 and 1954 and connecting Abidjan and Ouagadougou, was managed from 1960-1986 as a public corporation jointly owmed by Burkina and Cote d'lvoire (Regie des Chemins de Fer Abidjan- Niger, RAN). Initially the favored mode for all bulk and passenger transport between the coast and the Sahelian hinterland, the railways attained their operational peak in the mid- seventies, when RAN transported close to a million tons of freight and some 4 million passengers annually. In the late 1970s, operational and commercial performance of RAN declined, while the road networks in the region improved, and the port of Lome emerged as a competitor to Abidjan for Burkina traffic. With increasing competition from a rapidly developing trucking industry, the share of traffic carried from the coast to Burkina by rail and road respectively reversed from two-thirds/one-third in the mid-1970s to one-third/two-thirds in the late-1980s, turning an initially profitable entity into a loss-making one. 1.11 A 1982 Diagnostic Study of RAN (financed under a C6te d'Ivoire Technical Assistance Loan, Ln. 2059-IVC) identified the company's major problems and proposed a detailed financial rehabilitation plan. This was to be implemented over the 1984-1990 period, with the help of experienced expatriate management, and supported by an IDA Railway Rehabilitation Project. 1.12 Disagreements between the two co-owners prevented adoption of this plan and RAN's performance continued to deteriorate. In 1986, a decision in principle was taken to separate the railways into tmw national companies, Societe ivoirienne des chemins de fer (SICF) and Soci&e des chemins de fer du Burkina (SCFB); it took until 1989 for the two companies to become fully operational. As was easily foreseeable, this separation further exacerbated the inefficiencies in the provision of rail transport services in the corridor and led to more shifts of long distance traffic to road transport. 1.13 In an effort to stem and, if possible, reverse a trend that had reduced international tonnage transported by rail to less than 300,000 tons per year, the railway component of the Burkina Transport Sector Adjustment/Investment Program (Cr. 2332-BUR), approved by IDA in early 1992, required the establishment of a joint SCFB/SICF Office (Bureau de Trafic International, BTI) responsible for handling all international freight traffic and providing better service for commercial customers. Although BTI had some initial success, traffic (down to less than 220,000 tons in 1994) and revenue losses continued, and it became clear that only drastic restructuring could prevent the financial collapse of the two companies and their subsequent liquidation. 1.14 Consequently, in July 1992, the Governments of Burkina and Cote d'Ivoire announced their decision in principle to reunify and privatize railway operations on the Abidjan- Ouagadougou-Kaya axis, through a concession agreement to be signed with a private operator. A commission comprising representatives of the Privatization Commissions of CMte d'Ivoire and Burkina, the two ministries of transport, and of SICF and SCFB was set up to launch the process.

Advice and comments provided by IDA and co-donors' staff at the various stages of the process were substantially taken into account and significantly improved the design of the concession. Bids were launched in February 1993 and bid award (to a consortium led by major freight- forwarders operating in Western Africa) was made in July 1993. But it took seven negotiating sessions over a one-and-a-half year period before a Concession Agreement acceptable to all partners was signed on December 12, 1994. (A summary presentation of the concessionary company, SITARAIL is in ANNEX 1.1). The Concession Agreement became effective on August 20, 1995, and the Concessionaire took over operation of the railways on August 21, 1995. By that time, SCFB and SICF had been put into liquidation, and two new "patrimony corporations", Socite' Ivoirienne de Gestion du Patrimoine Ferroviaire (SIPF) and SociNd de Gestion du Patrimoine Ferroviaire BurAina (SOPAFER), had been created to hold the property of existing railway equipment and manage rail infrastructure on behalf of the two States. 1.16 The main features of the Concession Agreement are as follows: the concession is a "rolling concession" covering 15 years initially, with successive five-year extensions possible thereafter. The concessionaire (SITARAIL) operates commercial freight and passenger services in a fully-deregulated environment. SITARAIL is responsible for the maintenance of rail infrastructure and of leased motive power and rolling stock, the ownership of which remains with the two "patrimony corporations", SIPF and SOPAFER. The Concessionaire has rehired the personnel required (1,815) from among existing railway staff (3,470, of which some 1,370 in SCFB and some 2,100 in SICF). The Governments have provided severance payments to surplus staff not rehired by the private operator. Rehabilitation investments are proposed by the concessionaire. The two patrimony corporations handle borrowing on behalf of the two Governments who, although responsible for servicing the debt related to both infrastructure renewal and upgrading, and to equipment rehabilitation and acquisition, will recover these debt service payments fully from the concessionaire. The concession fee paid by the concessionaire to the Governments comprises: (i) an infrastructure user fee calculated as a percentage of the concessionaire's revenue; (ii) equipment lease payments, the calculation of which is defined in the Concession Agreement; and (iii) debt service coverage on the railway rehabilitation investments. Third-party rail service operators can be authorized after a 7-year exclusivity period. 1.17. The two patrimony corporations, SOPAFER and SIPF, are public sector companies charged with the administration of the railways' property on behalf of the two Governments. An agreement for the management of railway assets between the Ivorian Government and SIPF has been signed as a condition of presentation of the proposed Credit to the Board; publication of the Decree approving the agreement is a condition of credit effectiveness. D. Lessons from Previous Bank/IDA Projects and Rationale for IDA Involvement 1.18 IDA's involvement in the railway subsector dates back to 1978, when a Regional Railway Project (Ln. 1490-IVC/Cr. 744-UV) was approved that included improvement of track, renewal of rolling stock, and technical assistance and training for management and operations improvement of RAN. Its implementation took three years longer than foreseen, and railway performance deteriorated markedly over the project implementation period. In the absence of credible reform actions, a proposed follow-on rehabilitation program was not pursued (cf. para. 1.12 above). In the road subsector, where the Bank provided eight loans
 -5- between 1968 and 1985 for a total of US$333 million, including two Highway Sector loans of US$100 and US$110 million respectively, performance was somewhat better. But since the early 1990s, unwillingness to address the multiple problems of proper investment programming, maintenance funding and efficient works execution has made it difficult to justify continued IDA involvement in the sector. Thus, the project is the first IDA operation in Cote d'lvoire's transport sector since the Second Highway Sector Loan, which was approved in 1985 and closed in 1990, ending a ten-year hiatus that has been due to slow progress on sectoral reforms needed to make proposed investments sustainable. 1 .19 The rationale for proceeding with the project is that substantial reforms, fully consistent with IDA's country assistance strategy, have been decided on, and are being implemented, in the railway subsector (cf. paras. 1.14-1.15 above). Acceptable institutional arrangements, necessary for re-establishing competitive and efficient rail services in the Abidjan-Ouagadougou corridor, have been agreed upon by the two Governments and formally spelled out in the Concession Agreement (para. 1.16 above) that was signed with a private operator in December 1994, the first such arrangement in Sub-Saharan Africa. 1.20 IDA had been promoting reform and rehabilitation of the Abidjan-Ouagadougou railway for well over a decade, since it can have a demonstrable competitive advantage over road transport for certain types of traffic and can therefore play an important role in making the economies of both Burkina and of Cote d'lvoire more efficient. In the absence of the necessary restructuring and reform actions, earlier proposed projects were abandoned. But within the framework of the Concession Agreement, both the Burkina and the Cote d'Ivoire Governments have now agreed to the essential preconditions for efficient railway operations in a manner satisfactory to IDA and co-donors. The project is a major element for promoting the success of the concessioning of rail activities to the private sector in Cote d'lvoire and Burkina. This new arrangement for the operation of rail transport services fits very well with one of the main objectives of IDA's assistance strategy for both countries: Governments' disengagement from a major economic activity, which will henceforth be carried out by the private sector. Operating deficits of the two railway companies SICF and SCFB, which were borne by Government budgets, will be eliminated. More efficient rail services for freight transport will improve the competitiveness of the economies of both Cote d'Ivoire and Burkina. In addition, regional integration between Cote d'Ivoire and Burkina will be significantly strengthened.

Program and Project Objectives 2.1 The proposed project is part of a larger program for the overall rehabilitation of the full Abidjan/Ouagadougou/Kaya railways, covered by the Concession Agreement. The project covers the Ivorian component of the program; the Burkina part of the program, which has been appraised concurrently, is also fully financed (see para. 2.7 below). To reflect the fact that project justification intimately depends on the justification of the overall program, reference will be made in the following to either (or both) program and project objectives and characteristics, as appropriate. The main program and project objectives are to contribute to the revitalization of a major transport service promoting competitiveness and regional integration, by providing the financing necessary to carry out the long overdue rehabilitation of the publicly-owned railway infrastructure and equipment assets. These will be managed and operated by the private concessionaire, who needs the rehabilitation investments to enable it to provide efficient quality service. B. Program and Project Description 2.2 The proposed rehabilitation program is the first in support of a railway to be operated by a private concessionaire in Sub-Saharan Africa. As indicated above, the program will have two parts: * one in Cote d'lvoire, for the rehabilitation of railway equipment (motive power and rolling stock) owned by SIPF, and of railway infrastructure situated on Ivorian territory, for which financing will be channeled through SIPF, under the project, and * one in Burkina, for the rehabilitation of railway equipment (motive power and rolling stock) owned by SOPAFER, and of railway infrastructure situated on the Burkinabe territory, for which financing will be channeled through SOPAFER, under similar arrangements. 2.3 The main components of the program and their estimated base costs are as follows: (I) Infrastructure rehabilitation is estimated at US$29.9 million. It covers: (i) selective track renewal (75 km) and repair (41 km of sleepers and 66 km of rail replacement); (ii) ballasting ( 111 ,000 m3); (iii) bridge and culvert repairs; (iv) embankment repairs; (v) installation of weighing equipment; and (vi) some building repairs (workshops, stations). (II) Equipment rehabilitation and acquisition under the program is estimated at US$42.4 million overall. The motive powver and rolling stock rehabilitation component accounts for about US$30.8 million and covers: (i) the general overhaul or rehabilitation of 20 main-line locomotives; (ii) rehabilitation of 17 shunting locomotives; (iii) rehabilitation of 375 freight cars (out of a total of 600 leased by the Concessionaire); (iv) rehabilitation of 40 passenger coaches; and (v) establishment of a stock of essential spare parts. The maintenance equipment component, accounting for US$9.0 million, includes: (i) the rehabilitation and acquisition of essential track maintenance equipment and tools; and (ii) rehabilitation of maintenance facilities. A small telecommunication component accounts for US$1.8 million and covers: (i) the rehabilitation and improvement of the train-to-ground radio system; (ii) the installation of a radio block operating system; (iii) the replacement of PABX in the four major activities centers (Abidjan-Bouake-Bobo Dioulasso-Ouagadougou) and five medium size stations; and (iv) miscellaneous small repairs, acquisition of maintenance vehicles and establishment of a stock of essential spare parts. A last component is related to the acquisition of computers (US$0.8

doc.abstracts: The main objectives of Emergency Railway Rehabilitation Project are to contribute to the revitalization of a major transport service promoting competitiveness and regional integration, by providing the financing necessary to carry out the long overdue rehabilitation of the publicly-owned railway infrastructure and equipment assets. The main components of the project are as follows: 1) infrastructure rehabilitation which covers selective track renewal and repair, ballasting, bridge and culvert repairs, embankment repairs, installation of weighing equipment, and some building repairs; 2) equipment rehabilitation and acquisition including the motive power and rolling stock rehabilitation component, the maintenance equipment component, the telecommunication component, and the component related to the acquisition of computers; and 3) works supervision and training.
